observational_methods.question: In covert observation, participants:
options: Don't know they are being observed
Choose what to be observed doing

observational_methods.question: What is a weakness of observational methods?
options: They cannot establish cause and effect

observational_methods.question: What is an advantage of non-participant observation?
What is overt observation?
options: Participants don't know they're being observed

observational_methods.question: What is a disadvantage of covert observation?
Why might naturalistic observation have high ecological validity?
options: Behavior is studied in natural settings

observational_methods.question: Why might overt observation cause unnatural behavior?
What type of data do observations typically provide?
Why can't observational studies establish cause and effect?
options: No variables are manipulated by the researcher

observational_methods.question: What makes observations difficult to replicate exactly?
When might covert observation be justified?
options: When overt observation would change natural behavior

observational_methods.question: What is an advantage of structured observation?
options: Easier to analyze and compare data

self_report_methods.question: What is a closed question in a questionnaire?
options: A question that is difficult to answer
A question with fixed response options
A question that participants can skip

self_report_methods.question: What is social desirability bias?
options: Wanting to be popular with researchers
Giving answers that make you look good
Only talking to people you like

self_report_methods.question: Which type of interview is most flexible?
What is an open question?
options: A question with fixed response options
A question allowing free response in own words
A question that's easy to answer

self_report_methods.question: What is an advantage of closed questions?
What is a structured interview?
options: Same questions asked to all participants

self_report_methods.question: What is a disadvantage of open questions?
What is a leading question?
options: The first question in a survey
A question that suggests a particular answer
A question that's hard to understand

self_report_methods.question: What is a double-barreled question?
options: A question asking about two things at once
A question with two correct answers

self_report_methods.question: Why should jargon be avoided in questions?
options: Participants may not understand complex terms

self_report_methods.question: What is an advantage of self-report methods?
What memory limitation affects self-report accuracy?
options: People may not remember events accurately

self_report_methods.question: Why might people not be aware of their true motivations?
Why are large amounts of data an advantage?
What makes unstructured interviews difficult to analyze?
When might social desirability bias be strongest?
options: When questions are about neutral topics
When questions are about sensitive or personal topics

case_studies.question: What is a case study?
options: A study of many people briefly
An in-depth study of one individual or group
A study that takes one day

case_studies.question: What was significant about the Phineas Gage case study?
options: It showed the link between brain injury and personality
It showed all brain areas are the same

case_studies.question: What is a major weakness of case studies?
options: Results cannot be generalized to other people

case_studies.question: What was the Little Albert study about?
What did Patient HM's case study reveal?
options: Different types of memory systems exist

case_studies.question: What are neuropsychological case studies?
options: Studies of normal brain function only

case_studies.question: What data collection methods do case studies use?
options: Multiple methods including interviews, tests, observations

case_studies.question: Why do case studies have high ecological validity?
options: They study real-life situations in detail

case_studies.question: How do case studies generate hypotheses?
options: They provide ideas for future research to test

case_studies.question: Why can't case studies be replicated exactly?
What is researcher bias in case studies?
Why are rare conditions often studied through case studies?
options: Too few people have them for large-scale studies

case_studies.question: What makes case study data 'rich'?
options: It costs a lot of money

sampling_methods.question: What is opportunity sampling?
options: Selecting people randomly from a list
Using people who are easily available

sampling_methods.question: What is the target population?
options: All people the research aims to understand

sampling_methods.question: What is an advantage of random sampling?
What is systematic sampling?
options: Selecting every nth person from a list

sampling_methods.question: What is stratified sampling?
options: Random selection from the whole population
Population divided into subgroups, then random sample from each

sampling_methods.question: What is volunteer bias?
options: Volunteers may have certain personality types

sampling_methods.question: What is a disadvantage of small samples?
What does 'representative sample' mean?
options: Sample that reflects characteristics of the population

sampling_methods.question: When might snowball sampling be useful?
What is statistical power?
options: Ability to detect real effects in data

sampling_methods.question: Why might opportunity sampling be biased?
options: May not represent the whole population

sampling_methods.question: What makes stratified sampling representative?
options: Ensures all subgroups are included proportionally

sampling_methods.question: What is a disadvantage of random sampling?

ethics_in_research.question: What is informed consent?
options: Participants understanding what they're agreeing to

ethics_in_research.question: When might deception be acceptable in research?
options: When it makes the study easier
When there's no other way to study the behavior and no significant harm

ethics_in_research.question: What is debriefing?
options: Explaining the true purpose after participation

ethics_in_research.question: What is the right to withdraw?
options: Participants can take their data away
Participants can leave the study at any time

ethics_in_research.question: What is protection from harm?
options: Protecting from physical, psychological, and social harm

ethics_in_research.question: Why do children need special ethical consideration?
options: They may not fully understand what they're agreeing to

ethics_in_research.question: What do ethics committees do?
options: Review research proposals before studies begin

ethics_in_research.question: What was ethically problematic about Milgram's study?
options: It caused significant distress to participants

ethics_in_research.question: When is consent particularly important in naturalistic observation?
options: When people are in private spaces

ethics_in_research.question: What should debriefing include?
options: True purpose, addressing concerns, opportunity to withdraw data

ethics_in_research.question: What are vulnerable groups in research?
options: People who may need extra protection (children, mentally ill, prisoners)

ethics_in_research.question: Why must benefits outweigh risks?
options: To ensure research is ethically justified

ethics_in_research.question: What is social harm?
options: Harm to society as a whole

ethics_in_research.question: Why is anonymity important in research?
options: Protects participants from potential negative consequences

ethics_in_research.question: What must researchers consider when balancing ethics and research value?
options: Scientific value, benefits to society, risks to participants

research_evaluation.question: What is generalisability in research?
options: Whether findings can apply to other people and situations

research_evaluation.question: What is population generalisability?
options: How many people live in an area
Whether results apply to other groups of people
The size of the sample used

research_evaluation.question: What is reliability in research?
options: Consistency of results when study is repeated

research_evaluation.question: What is test-retest reliability?
options: Getting the same results when the test is repeated over time
Using different tests for different people
Testing people multiple times in one session

research_evaluation.question: What is inter-observer reliability?
options: Different researchers getting the same results

research_evaluation.question: What is internal validity?
options: Whether the study is conducted inside
Whether the IV really causes changes in the DV
How internal the research team is

research_evaluation.question: What is external validity?
options: Whether the study is conducted outside
Whether results apply to real-world settings
Whether the study uses external funding

research_evaluation.question: What is ecological validity?
options: How environmentally friendly the research is
Whether results apply to real-life situations

research_evaluation.question: What are confounding variables?
options: Other factors that might affect the results

research_evaluation.question: What is applicability in research?
options: How easy it is to apply for research funding
How useful findings are in real-world contexts
How applicable the research methods are

research_evaluation.question: What are demand characteristics?
options: When participants guess the aim and change behavior

research_evaluation.question: What is the Hawthorne effect?
options: When behavior changes because people know they're being observed

research_evaluation.question: What is temporal validity?
options: Whether findings apply across different time periods

research_evaluation.question: Laboratory experiments typically have:
options: High internal validity but low ecological validity

research_evaluation.question: Case studies typically have:
options: Poor generalisability but rich detailed data

research_evaluation.question: What is cultural validity?
options: Whether findings apply across different cultures
Whether the study uses cultural methods

research_evaluation.question: Naturalistic observations typically have:
options: High ecological validity but low internal validity

research_evaluation.question: When evaluating ethics, we consider:
options: Only the cost of the research
Whether participants were protected from harm and gave consent
